content: The "Homeowner Opportunity Act of 2008" may increase loan limits for high-cost areas for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The "Homeowner Opportunity Act of 2008" may raise loan limits for high-cost areas for Fannie Mae, with a new provision for mortgages originated on or after January 1, 2009. The maximum original principal obligation of a mortgage purchased by the corporation shall be the higher of the limitation determined for a residence of the applicable size or 125 percent of the area median price for a residence. The Homeowner Opportunity Act of 2008 may increase loan limits for high-cost areas for Fannie Mae, with a provision for mortgages originated on or after January 1, 2009. The maximum original principal obligation of a mortgage purchased by the corporation shall be 125-175 percent of the area median price for a residence of the applicable size. The Homeowner Opportunity Act of 2008 may increase loan limits for high-cost areas for Fannie Mae, with a provision for mortgages originated on or after January 1, 2009. The maximum original principal obligation of a mortgage purchased by the corporation shall be the higher of 125 percent of the area median price for a residence of the applicable size or 175 percent of the limitation determined under subparagraph (A) for a residence of the applicable size. The Homeowner Opportunity Act of 2008 may increase loan limits for high-cost areas for Fannie Mae, with a provision for mortgages originated on or after January 1, 2009. The areas and area median prices used for determining the limits shall be those used by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Congress emphasizes the importance of mortgage securitization by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in providing liquidity to the housing markets. The Homeowner Opportunity Act of 2008 may increase loan limits for high-cost areas for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to securitize mortgages efficiently without additional costs.
